headline: Simple Vinaigrette Recipe
description: Note: Why bother emulsifying your vinaigrette? Read about the science of emulsions. [Photographs: J. Kenji Lopez-Alt] This recipes make a cup of vinaigrette. Extra vinaigrette can be stored in a sealed container in the refrigerator indefinitely....
name: Simple Vinaigrette Recipe
keywords: salad, salad dressing, The Food Lab, vinaigrette
recipeIngredient: 3 tablespoons white wine vinegar or lemon juice
1/4 cup flavored oil (such as extra-virgin olive oil)

recipeInstructions.text:
Combine all ingredients in small container or squeeze bottle. Seal container and shake vigorously until emulsified. Shake again before each use. This Recipe Appears In 
 How to Make Vinaigrette (and Dress Your Salad Right) 
 The Food Lab: What's the Point of a Vinaigrette? 
 The OXO Good Grips Salad Dressing Shaker Makes Me Eat More Salad 
 Serious Entertaining: Early Spring Dinner

review.reviewBody:
Kenji,

How does one make those incredibly light yet flavorful dressings typically served at high end restaurants? Sometimes you can barely tell there's dressing on the salad, yet the flavors are all there. I've found that by using walnut oil I can achieve a fraction of this lightness, but at the expense of adding nuttiness that may or may not be welcome. 

Thanks for all your hard work btw, I enjoy your articles and recipes immensely, and in turn do all my house guests!

As the previous poster mentioned, the recipe doesn't match the Food Lab article. I was looking for the same recipe referenced in the article, as I was curious if it mentioned the shelf-life with the addition of shallots and garlic. For anyone else looking for the same recipe the Food Lab article is all about: https://www.seriouseats.com/simple-vinaigrette-recipe
FYI, the recipe that is linked is different. The ingredients are similar but the techniques are totally different..

I keep mine in a squeeze bottle in the fridge. If the oil solidifies, just throw it in the microwave for 15 seconds and you should be good. Alternatively, run it under a hot tap for 30 seconds. Always cover the top and shake vigorously before using!

Love your articles. Always very informative. Question, though...we often make too much vinaigrette (jar shaken, similar to you) for dinner and stick it in fridge hoping to reuse it on a future salad. But it separates over time (expected) the oil always solidifies making it useless. Or at least more complicated/time-consuming to use than just making a new one. Any thoughts?
